data.title: William Rudolf O'Donovan
data.meta_description: Description: Shows O'Donovan with bust of Walt Whitman. Annotated "From a negative made by Thomas Eakins-the painter in his studio in Philadelphia, May 1891, To Lulu O'Donovan from her uncle William Rudolf O'Donovan, Nov. 20, 1891." O'Donovan was a sculptor, New York, N.Y. Creator/Photographer: Thomas Eakins Birth Date: 1844 Death Date: 1916 A native of Philadelphia, Thomas Eakins has long been considered one of the foremost American painters of the 19th century. The photographs associated with his work are extremely varied, including portraits, posed nudes, studies of figures in motion, and casual images of friends and family. These images exist as cyanotypes, platinum enlargements, and album contact prints measuring four by five inches. While many seem directly related to his paintings, others are only tangentially or ambiguously associated, and some are not connected at all. It is difficult to attribute photographs to Eakins in several cases because many of his students, friends, and family members also experimented with the camera. Recent scholarship has revealed much new information about the artist's use of photography and suggests that he projected photographic images directly onto the canvas as a step in producing a painting. Medium: Black and white photographic print Dimensions: 6 cm x 8 cm Date: 1891 Repository: Archives of American Art Accession number: AAA_miscphot_8247
data.text:
Description: Shows O'Donovan with bust of Walt Whitman. Annotated "From a negative made by Thomas Eakins-the painter in his studio in Philadelphia, May 1891, To Lulu O'Donovan from her uncle William Rudolf O'Donovan, Nov. 20, 1891." O'Donovan was a sculptor, New York, N.Y.

Creator/Photographer: Thomas Eakins

Birth Date: 1844

Death Date: 1916

A native of Philadelphia, Thomas Eakins has long been considered one of the foremost American painters of the 19th century. The photographs associated with his work are extremely varied, including portraits, posed nudes, studies of figures in motion, and casual images of friends and family. These images exist as cyanotypes, platinum enlargements, and album contact prints measuring four by five inches. While many seem directly related to his paintings, others are only tangentially or ambiguously associated, and some are not connected at all. It is difficult to attribute photographs to Eakins in several cases because many of his students, friends, and family members also experimented with the camera. Recent scholarship has revealed much new information about the artist's use of photography and suggests that he projected photographic images directly onto the canvas as a step in producing a painting.

Medium: Black and white photographic print

Dimensions: 6 cm x 8 cm

Date: 1891

Repository: Archives of American Art

Accession number: AAA_miscphot_8247
